question.title: Java Desktop#browse fails for specific URI
question.body:
In my Java desktop application I try to launch an URI in the current default browser like this:

Desktop.getDesktop().browse(URI(uri))

Normally this works without problems but for the uri string "https://jfspwa.java-forum-stuttgart.de" I only get an exception:

Failed to mail or browse https://jfspwa.java-forum-stuttgart.de. Error code: -10827
java.io.IOException: Failed to mail or browse https://jfspwa.java-forum-stuttgart.de. Error code: -10827
    at java.desktop/sun.lwawt.macosx.CDesktopPeer.lsOpen(CDesktopPeer.java:169)
    at java.desktop/sun.lwawt.macosx.CDesktopPeer.browse(CDesktopPeer.java:74)
    at java.desktop/java.awt.Desktop.browse(Desktop.java:533)

The URI is valid though and if I just copy/paste it into the browser it works without problem. What is this error message going to tell me? What can make an URI inaccessible from Java but accessible directly? I am clueless. First I thought it may be because of the sub-domain but I tried it with another URI with sub-domain and that one worked.

I tried this on macOS 14.7.5, Java Temurin 21.0.6+7-LTS and all browsers (Firefox, Safari and Chrome) with their latest versions.

answers.body: I just ran the test on a newer machine with macOS 15.5 and everything worked. This must be a strange Apple bug which seems to be fixed in the latest versions of the OS.

question_comments.body: This question is in no way related to Kotlin because it only refers to a problem with a pure Java API. The fact that I originally called it from Kotlin and forgot to add the "new" keyword in the question is irrelevant for the question as such and tagging it with Kotlin would therefore just be misleading.
( one more reason why I don't love Kotlin code questions tagged with the java tag - from its tooltip: "Use this tag when you're having problems using or understanding the language itself." )

Ah, now I got you. You are right of course but this is not the problem here because I actually used this from Kotlin and there you don't need the 'new'. Sorry that I missed that and caused some confusion.
but that (public URI(String str)) is a constructor, no return type given at all, not even void, that means, I must complete my comment, you must use new URI(uri) (at least in Java)
Yes, I did use URI(uri) and not URI.create(uri). See docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/21/docs/api/java.base/java/ne‌​t/… The result should be basically the same.

I was not refering to the String in uri, I posted it in parenthesis (trying to avoid confusion) - note you posted ...browse(URI(uri)), not ...browse(URI.create(uri)) - probably missing ",create" or the method "URI()"

@user85421 What exactly do you mean? Of course uri is supposed to hold the string value you have cited, or are you refering to the URI.create? I did use the constructor variant as shown in my code line.
works for me too, but (obviously?) I had to use ...browse(URI.create(uri)) (with var uri = "https://jfspwa.java-forum-stuttgart.de" )

Works fine for me on macOS 15.6, Java 24.0.2, Safari 18.6. Error -10827 looks like it may be the kLSNoExecutableErr Launch Services error "The executable is missing" - I've not idea what that means here.
